content.content: Hi Maker community. I’m Ari Paul, CIO and co-founder of BlockTower.  I want to share BlockTower’s involvement with MakerDAO and the “real world lending” space, our current vision for this ecosystem, and how we hope to work alongside you to build towards that vision. We’ve been MKR token holders since March, 2020 and have been ramping up our public support over the last year as we’ve spent more time and had growing excitement about the ecosystem.  Around June of last year I went “all-in” mentally on what Maker is tackling.  Last summer I became convinced that “real world lending” A. had the potential for massive, sustainable, real growth and value creation, and B.  that this was a niche where BlockTower could be leaders and valuable long-term partners (unlike many other niches where we lack the technical expertise to partner deeply, like in ZK research for example.) “Real world lending” became a key focus for BlockTower a little over a year ago with this framing: I’m not sure how this plays out over the next 5-10 years.  I don’t know what the best investments will be, the winning business models, nor the smartest way for us to add value and participate in the ‘stack.’  What I want to bet on is this:  “real world lending” will create sustainable value over the next 5 years and real disruption over 10.  And if BlockTower can build industry leading expertise in key parts of the stack and establish ourselves as the most trusted partners for anyone building on this theme over the next decade, good things will happen for the industry and for us.”  Everything that BlockTower is doing today is with an eye towards a decade out prize – the prize of helping build a cryptocurrency native monetary system that disrupts the existing tradfi system. We’re not sure exactly which parts of the stack we’ll be involved in over time, but for now, we’re going where it seems we’re needed and where we have competency for our “active” efforts.  BlockTower as a firm is involved in this theme from many angles.  We make VC investments in projects tackling parts of the RWL stack, we have made $50m+ in loans through platforms like Maple, we buy tokens of liquid projects like Maker and Centrifuge.  But…this wasn’t enough.  In evaluating this sector last year and thinking through how we as an industry can bootstrap it to maturity, at least two “hard parts” became clear: The “hard parts” we hope to help with: A.	Principal-agent problems in credit underwriting.  In brief – it’s hard to assess credit investments – that’s a specialized skillset that few people have.  “DYOR” doesn’t work for credit; I have an MBA, am a CFA charterholder, and have spent 17 years now as a professional investor, and after spending 6 months trying to brush up on credit last year, I realized I have absolutely no business allocating credit on behalf of MakerDAO or anyone else.  I quickly brought on the experienced credit pro Kevin Miao whom many of you have gotten to know, and he’s built out his team with other credit pros. At least during an initial bootstrapping phase, it’s likely that “trusted intermediaries” are critical to help get us from “0 to 1.”  Maybe in a few years, we’ll have both technological and social infrastructure to fully distintermediate credit underwriters.  If so – great!  Our goal isn’t to monetize rent seeking behavior – the opposite – it’s to help bootstrap things quickly to the point that this maybe isn’t necessary, or at least to a point where users have the choice.  And there’s no incentive conflict there for us given our many “bites at the apple” in the form of token and equity ownership etc. B.	 Onboarding tradfi lenders.  At maturity, we all hope defi will be more trustworthy, more transparent, and better UX than tradfi finance.  But that’s certainly not true for new platforms with experimental designs at launch.  Consider a typical pension or family office that invests in say, corporate debt.  Their team that allocates to corporate debt are experienced credit allocators.  These people are usually neither particularly entrepreneurial nor expert technologists.  Asking them to evaluate a new tech and game theory platform to entrust with their pensioners’ life savings…basically it’s just not gonna happen.  As with, say, BTC adoption, it has to follow a path towards being trusted by “normies.”  Before endowments and pensions were willing to own crypto directly, they first invested via intermediaries like Grayscale (via GBTC) or other types of regulated investment products. Only after companies like Coinbase and Fidelity achieved sufficient scale or brought pre-existing credibility (as well as various regulatory licensing), were most institutions comfortable with direct ownership.  And even today, very few institutions are comfortable holding their own keys.  It’s either ownership via trusted intermediary or nothing, for now. During the bootstrapping phase, we hope we can add value by acting as that trusted conduit bringing capital to MakerDAO and into crypto more generally.  To make tradfi investors comfortable with on-chain investments, we spent the last year producing a 40-page document with detailed analysis of every legal, operational, and even tax implication that we and prospective investors can think of, for these investments.  Even digesting the content of those document are beyond the ambitions of most tradfi institutions today (not because they’re unable, but because that amount of research just to explore a new platform is not what professional investors in tradfi are used to doing – it’s not generally part of their jobs.)  We hope that the combination of our diligent work and brand will enable us to bring billions of dollars of new capital into this ecosystem to finance bringing billions of dollars of debt on-chain over the next 5 years. One of our investment vehicles is a substantial holder of MKR.  I can’t legally commit to future actions of this vehicle, but our MKR holdings are public and I hope I have the opportunity to double down.  Our basket of “real world lending” investments will grow and evolve over time, but everything we hold today on that theme, we intend to hold for many years.  That’s not a promise, it’s just my honest intention.  I bought MKR long before we ever had the idea to partner with the DAO, because I was bullish on the community, the leadership, and the vision.  As we now have a substantial portion of BlockTower as a firm focused on partnering with MKR over the next decade, I’m actively “sizing up” the relationship, and I hope more token buys can follow over time as our balance sheet allows. Our credit team has worked tirelessly to preserve Maker’s values while extending the community’s impact. If you haven’t already, please refer to their ongoing proposals (MIP6 and MIP90).  We’re honored and excited to work alongside key members of the community in navigating frontiers in this regard. (see BlockTower’s Spring Protector Cluster announcement here). We greatly appreciate the continued dialogue with the community, so please do not hesitate to reach out to me or our team with any matter of discussion. Thanks, Ari DISCLAIMER: Any projections or forecasts contained in this document are speculative in nature, as matters they describe are subject to known (and unknown) risks, uncertainties and other unpredictable factors. Investing in newer and smaller asset classes such as cryptocurrencies is speculative, risky and unsuitable for some investors even when representing only a portion of a broader investment program. The graphs, charts and other visual aids are provided for informational purposes only. No representation is made that these will assist any person in making investment decisions and no graph, chart or other visual aid can capture all factors and variables required in making such decisions. Certain links, too, are provided as a convenience and do not imply the Adviser’s sponsorship or approval of any third-party websites or their content.

Good morning Maker community (or evening for our friends in Asia).  Those of you following our MKR holdings on-chain will likely see us move some of our position into AMM pools. We have no interest in selling, just looking to earn some yield on the tokens and help increase MKR liquidity. We expect to increase our exposure overall through these efforts.
Can you provide the anticipated return? Is it possible to cast votes in polls if your MKR is held in automated market maker (AMM) pools?

Thanks @TRUEMAKER. Anticipated returns continue to be primarily driven by our long-term investment thesis and support in MKR. In the interim, supporting liquidity on AMMs helps provide secondary returns that will be subject to the levels at which we concentrate liquidity and available fee tiers, see current 0.3% and 1% fee tier Uniswap v3 pool options. As for voting, we will be unable to vote our MKR tokens while holding a LP position on protocols like Uniswap, but will likely close our LP position as Maker Governance resumes in 2023 and the voting cycle resumes. – Disclaimers noted in the original post above
